standards: 2.1.1 Counting numbers up to 1000 in ascending and descending order
objectives: Students are able to count numbers up to 1000 in ascending and descending order fluently.
activities: Using a large number line on the floor to walk while counting
Game 'Number Jump' – students jump to specific numbers
Singing counting songs 100–1000

standards: 2.1.2 Writing and comparing numbers up to 1000
objectives: Students are able to write numbers up to 1000 in numerals and compare two numbers using the symbols >, <, =.
activities: Filling in the blanks on a number table
Game 'Bigger Number' – comparing number cards
Using base-10 blocks to build and compare numbers

standards: 2.2.1 Adding two numbers up to 1000 without regrouping
objectives: Students are able to solve addition number sentences up to 1000 without regrouping using concrete objects or algorithms.
activities: Using an abacus for addition without regrouping
Writing number sentences on the whiteboard
Game 'Quick Addition' in pairs

standards: 2.2.2 Adding two numbers up to 1000 with regrouping
objectives: Students are able to solve addition number sentences up to 1000 with regrouping using base-10 blocks or algorithms.
activities: Using base-10 blocks to show the regrouping process
Activity 'Break the Hundred' – from 10 tens to 1 hundred
Solving daily problems: 'Ali has 456 marbles, gets 278 more'

standards: 2.3.1 Subtracting two numbers up to 1000 without regrouping
objectives: Students are able to solve subtraction number sentences up to 1000 without regrouping using concrete objects or algorithms.
activities: Using an abacus for subtraction without regrouping
Writing subtraction sentences on cards
Game 'Take & Count' – take objects and count the remainder

standards: 2.3.2 Subtracting two numbers up to 1000 with regrouping
objectives: Students are able to solve subtraction number sentences up to 1000 with regrouping using base-10 blocks or algorithms.
activities: Using base-10 blocks to show the borrowing process
Activity 'Borrow One' – converting 1 hundred into 10 tens
Solving daily problems: 'Mother has 800 beans, uses 345'

standards: 2.4.1 Recognizing the concept of multiplication as repeated addition (tables 2, 5, 10)
objectives: Students are able to state multiplication as repeated addition (e.g., 3 × 5 = 5 + 5 + 5).
activities: Using picture cards to show groups (e.g., 4 groups of 5 apples)
Singing rhythmic 2, 5, 10 times tables
Building number sentences from group pictures
assessment: Matching repeated addition with multiplication worksheets

standards: 2.4.2 Stating basic multiplication facts for tables 2, 5, 10 spontaneously
objectives: Students are able to state basic multiplication facts for tables 2, 5, 10 quickly and accurately.
activities: 1-minute times table quiz
Card game 'Times Table Match'
Times table 5 number jump (5, 10, 15...)
assessment: Record of time taken to answer 10 times table questions

standards: 2.5.1 Recognizing the concept of division as regrouping (tables 2, 5, 10)
objectives: Students are able to state division as regrouping (e.g., 10 ÷ 2 = 5 groups of 2).
activities: Dividing marbles into containers equally
Using picture cards to show division as groups
Game 'Equal Sharing' with toy objects
kategori: Division as Regrouping and Equal Sharing

standards: 2.5.2 Recognizing the concept of division as equal sharing (tables 2, 5, 10)
objectives: Students are able to state division as equal sharing (e.g., 10 ÷ 2 = 5 given to 2 people).
activities: Sharing toy candies with friends
Short role-play: 'I have 15 candies, share with 5 friends'
Using base-10 blocks to show division
kategori: Division as Regrouping and Equal Sharing

standards: 2.6.1 Recognizing and naming fractions ½, ⅓, ¼ as part of a whole
objectives: Students are able to identify and name fractions ½, ⅓, ¼ through folding and equal parts.
activities: Folding paper into 2, 3, 4 equal parts
Coloring one part of a divided shape
Using toy pizza to show fractions
assessment: Oral Q&A: 'Is this ⅓ or ¼?'
kategori: Understanding and Naming Simple Proper Fractions

standards: 2.6.2 Comparing fractions ½, ⅓, ¼ using visual models
objectives: Students are able to compare the size of fractions ½, ⅓, ¼ and state which is larger/smaller.
activities: Arranging fraction cards by size
Using paper circles to compare the size of parts
Game 'Largest Fraction' in groups
assessment: Oral assessment: 'Which is larger, ½ or ¼?'
aids: Paper circles to cut and compare
kategori: Understanding and Naming Simple Proper Fractions

standards: 2.7.1 Recognizing and counting money value up to RM100
objectives: Students are able to identify and count total money up to RM100 using coins and banknotes.
activities: Toy shop: buying items with play money
Totaling money in a bag and recording the amount
Matching money cards with values (RM50, RM20, etc.)
assessment: Observation during the toy shop game
kategori: Recognizing, Counting, and Solving Problems Involving Money

standards: 2.7.2 Solving simple daily problems involving money up to RM100
objectives: Students are able to solve daily situations such as buying items and finding change using addition/subtraction.
activities: Role-play: 'Buy bread for RM2, pay RM5, how much change?'
Using money problem story cards
Building number sentences from real situations
aids: Actual objects (plastic bread, toy water bottles)
kategori: Recognizing, Counting, and Solving Problems Involving Money

standards: 2.8.1 Reading time on an analog clock up to five minutes
objectives: Students are able to read and state the time on an analog clock up to five minutes (e.g., 3.15, 4.25).
activities: Using a large analog clock to show time
Game 'Show the Time' in pairs
Drawing clock hands on an empty clock face
kategori: Reading Time and Relationship Between Time Units

standards: 2.8.2 Knowing the relationship between time units (days and weeks, months and years)
objectives: Students are able to state the relationship between days–weeks and months–years (e.g., 1 week = 7 days, 1 year = 12 months).
activities: Using a calendar to count days in a week/month
Game 'Count the Days' – how many days in 2 weeks?
Building a time unit relationship chart
assessment: Oral Q&A: 'How many months in a year?'
aids: Time relationship chart (days, weeks, months, years)
kategori: Reading Time and Relationship Between Time Units

standards: 2.9.1 Measuring the length of objects using standard units (cm, m)
objectives: Students are able to measure the length of objects such as books, tables, or string using a ruler or measuring tape in cm and m units.
activities: Measuring the length of textbooks and recording in cm
Measuring peer height using a measuring tape
Game 'Who is Longest?' – measuring strings

standards: 2.9.2 Measuring mass and liquid volume using standard units (g, kg, ml, liter)
objectives: Students are able to measure the mass of light objects (g/kg) and liquid volume (ml/liter) using scales and beakers.
activities: Weighing light fruits in grams
Pouring water into a beaker and reading the volume in ml
Game 'Which Volume is More?'
assessment: Oral Q&A: 'How many grams is this?'

standards: 2.10.1 Describing the properties of 2D shapes (number of sides, vertices)
objectives: Students are able to identify and state the number of sides and vertices for 2D shapes such as squares, triangles, and circles.
activities: Using 2D shape cards to count sides and vertices
Building shapes with ice cream sticks and counting properties
Game 'Find the Property' – teacher names a property, student shows the shape
assessment: Oral assessment: 'How many vertices does a triangle have?'

standards: 2.10.2 Describing the properties of 3D shapes (surfaces, vertices, straight/curved edges)
objectives: Students are able to identify and state the properties of 3D shapes such as cubes, cuboids, and spheres (e.g., flat or curved surfaces).
activities: Touching and describing the properties of 3D shapes
Building towers with 3D shapes and describing properties
Game 'Guess the Shape' – teacher describes properties, student guesses

standards: 2.11.1 Constructing simple bar charts based on collected data
objectives: Students are able to construct simple bar charts using collected data (e.g., friends' favorite colors).
activities: Collecting data on friends' favorite colors
Using blocks or stickers to build a bar chart
Labeling horizontal and vertical axes

standards: 2.11.2 Interpreting information from simple bar charts
objectives: Students are able to read and interpret information from bar charts (e.g., most popular color, how many people like blue).
activities: Interpreting their own constructed bar charts
Q&A: 'Which is the most?', 'How many people like red?'
Game 'Guess the Answer' based on the chart
